Dual Norm

Posted on 2021-06-08

Minkowski norm

Let S⊂RdS \subset \mathbb{R}^dS⊂Rd be a convex set. It is symmetric if S=−SS = -SS=−S, where

−S≐{−v⃗:v⃗∈S}. -S \doteq \{ - \vec v : \vec v \in S \}. −S≐{−v:v∈S}.

The Minkowski norm ∥x⃗∥S\Vert \vec x \Vert_S∥x∥S​ induced by the convex body SSS is defined as

∥x⃗∥S≐inf⁡{r∈R≥0:x⃗∈rS}, \Vert \vec x \Vert_S \doteq \inf \{ r \in \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0} : \vec x \in r S \}, ∥x∥S​≐inf{r∈R≥0​:x∈rS},

where rS≐{rv⃗:v⃗∈S}r S \doteq \{ r \vec v : \vec v \in S \}rS≐{rv:v∈S}.

Fact ∥⋅∥S\Vert \cdot \Vert_S∥⋅∥S​ is is a norm.

Proof.

  1. For all x⃗∈Rd\vec x \in \mathbb{R}^dx∈Rd, ∥x⃗∥S≥0\Vert \vec x \Vert_S \ge 0∥x∥S​≥0.

  2. For all c∈R,x⃗∈Rdc \in \mathbb{R}, \vec x \in \mathbb{R}^dc∈R,x∈Rd, ∥cx⃗∥S=∣c∣⋅∥x⃗∥S\Vert c \vec x \Vert_S = |c| \cdot \Vert \vec x \Vert_S∥cx∥S​=∣c∣⋅∥x∥S​.

  3. For all x⃗,y⃗∈Rd\vec x, \vec y \in \mathbb{R}^dx,y​∈Rd, ∥x⃗+y⃗∥S≤∥x⃗∥S+∥y⃗∥S\Vert \vec x + \vec y \Vert_S \le \Vert \vec x \Vert_S + \Vert \vec y \Vert_S∥x+y​∥S​≤∥x∥S​+∥y​∥S​.

    The claim is trivial if ∥x⃗∥S\Vert \vec x \Vert_S∥x∥S​ or ∥y⃗∥S=0\Vert \vec y \Vert_S = 0∥y​∥S​=0. Otherwise,

    ∥x⃗+y⃗∥S≤∥x⃗∥S+∥y⃗∥S⟺∥∥x⃗∥S∥x⃗∥S+∥y⃗∥S⋅x⃗∥x⃗∥S+∥y⃗∥S∥x⃗∥S+∥y⃗∥S⋅y⃗∥y⃗∥S∥S≤1 \begin{aligned} &\Vert \vec x + \vec y \Vert_S \le \Vert \vec x \Vert_S + \Vert \vec y \Vert_S \\ \Longleftrightarrow &\left\Vert \frac{ \Vert \vec x \Vert_S }{ \Vert \vec x \Vert_S + \Vert \vec y \Vert_S } \cdot \frac{ \vec x }{ \Vert \vec x \Vert_S } + \frac{ \Vert \vec y \Vert_S }{ \Vert \vec x \Vert_S + \Vert \vec y \Vert_S } \cdot \frac{ \vec y }{ \Vert \vec y \Vert_S } \right\Vert_S &\le 1 \\ \end{aligned} ⟺​∥x+y​∥S​≤∥x∥S​+∥y​∥S​∥∥∥∥∥​∥x∥S​+∥y​∥S​∥x∥S​​⋅∥x∥S​x​+∥x∥S​+∥y​∥S​∥y​∥S​​⋅∥y​∥S​y​​∥∥∥∥∥​S​​≤1​

    It suffices to assume that ∥x⃗∥S=∥y⃗∥S=1\Vert \vec x \Vert_S = \Vert \vec y \Vert_S = 1∥x∥S​=∥y​∥S​=1.
    But this implies that x,y∈Sx , y \in Sx,y∈S.
    Since SSS is convex, for a,b∈R≥0a, b \in \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0}a,b∈R≥0​, s.t., a+b=1a + b = 1a+b=1, we have

    a⋅x⃗+b⋅y⃗∈S. a \cdot \vec x + b \cdot \vec y \in S. a⋅x+b⋅y​∈S.

Remark: More rigorously, we require that 0⃗\vec 00 is an inner point of SSS, so that

∥x⃗∥S=0  ⟺  x⃗=0⃗. \Vert \vec x \Vert_S = 0 \iff \vec x = \vec 0. ∥x∥S​=0⟺x=0.

□\square□

Dual Norm

The polar body S∗S^*S∗ of SSS is defined as

{u⃗∈Rd:<u⃗,v⃗>≤1 ∀v⃗∈S}. \{ \vec u \in \mathbb{R}^d : \left< \vec u, \vec v \right> \le 1 \, \forall \vec v \in S \}. {u∈Rd:⟨u,v⟩≤1∀v∈S}.

Fact. If SSS is convex and symmetric, so is S∗S^*S∗.

Proof. For all y⃗,z⃗∈S∗\vec y, \vec z \in S^*y​,z∈S∗, and a,b∈[0,1]a, b \in [0, 1]a,b∈[0,1], such that a+b=1a + b = 1a+b=1, we have

sup⁡v⃗∈S<v⃗,a⋅y⃗+b⋅z⃗>≤sup⁡v⃗∈S<v⃗,a⋅y⃗>+sup⁡v⃗∈S<v⃗,b⋅z⃗>≤a+b=1. \sup_{ \vec v \in S} \left< \vec v, a \cdot \vec y + b \cdot \vec z \right> \le \sup_{ \vec v \in S} \left< \vec v, a \cdot \vec y \right> + \sup_{ \vec v \in S} \left< \vec v, b \cdot \vec z \right> \le a + b = 1. v∈Ssup​⟨v,a⋅y​+b⋅z⟩≤v∈Ssup​⟨v,a⋅y​⟩+v∈Ssup​⟨v,b⋅z⟩≤a+b=1.

It is trivial to prove that S∗S^*S∗ is also symmetric.

□\square□

Definition. The Minkowski norm induced by S∗S^*S∗ (if it is convex and symmetric) is the dual norm of ∥⋅∥S\Vert \cdot \Vert_S∥⋅∥S​, and is defined as

∥y⃗∥S∗≐sup⁡x⃗∈S<x⃗,y⃗>, \Vert \vec y \Vert_{S^*} \doteq \sup_{ \vec x \in S } \left< \vec x, \vec y \right>, ∥y​∥S∗​≐x∈Ssup​⟨x,y​⟩,

or equivalently,

∥y⃗∥S∗≐sup⁡<x⃗,y⃗>,  s.t., ∥x⃗∥S=1. \Vert \vec y \Vert_{S^*} \doteq \sup \left< \vec x, \vec y \right>, \, \text{ s.t., } \Vert \vec x \Vert_S = 1. ∥y​∥S∗​≐sup⟨x,y​⟩, s.t., ∥x∥S​=1.

Proof. To verify the norm is well defined, we need to prove that

  1. For all y⃗∈Rd\vec y \in \mathbb{R}^dy​∈Rd, ∥y⃗∥S∗≥0\Vert \vec y \Vert_{S^*} \ge 0∥y​∥S∗​≥0.
  2. For all c∈R,y⃗∈Rdc \in \mathbb{R}, \vec y \in \mathbb{R}^dc∈R,y​∈Rd, ∥cy⃗∥S∗=∣c∣⋅∥y⃗∥S∗\Vert c \vec y \Vert_{S^*} = |c| \cdot \Vert \vec y \Vert_{S^*}∥cy​∥S∗​=∣c∣⋅∥y​∥S∗​.
  3. For all y⃗,z⃗∈Rd\vec y, \vec z \in \mathbb{R}^dy​,z∈Rd, ∥y⃗+z⃗∥S∗≤∥y⃗∥S∗+∥z⃗∥S∗\Vert \vec y + \vec z \Vert_{S^*} \le \Vert \vec y \Vert_{S^*} + \Vert \vec z \Vert_{S^*}∥y​+z∥S∗​≤∥y​∥S∗​+∥z∥S∗​.

The first two properties are obvious. The triangle inequality follows from that

sup⁡∥x∥S=1<x,y⃗+z⃗>≤sup⁡∥x∥S=1<x,y⃗>+sup⁡∥x∥S=1<x,z⃗>. \sup_{ \Vert x \Vert_S = 1} \left< x, \vec y + \vec z \right> \le \sup_{ \Vert x \Vert_S = 1} \left< x, \vec y \right> + \sup_{ \Vert x \Vert_S = 1} \left< x, \vec z \right>. ∥x∥S​=1sup​⟨x,y​+z⟩≤∥x∥S​=1sup​⟨x,y​⟩+∥x∥S​=1sup​⟨x,z⟩.

□\square□

Fact. For p,q∈[1,∞]p, q \in [1, \infty]p,q∈[1,∞], s.t., 1p+1q=1\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1p1​+q1​=1, ∥⋅∥p\Vert \cdot \Vert_p∥⋅∥p​ is the dual norm of ∥⋅∥q\Vert \cdot \Vert_q∥⋅∥q​.

Proof. Let

S≐{x⃗∈Rd:(∑i∈[d]∣xi∣p)1/p≤1}. S \doteq \Big\{ \vec x \in \mathbb{R}^d : \Big( \sum_{i \in [d] } |x_i|^p \Big)^{1 / p} \le 1 \Big\}. S≐{x∈Rd:(i∈[d]∑​∣xi​∣p)1/p≤1}.

By definition, we need to prove that for all y⃗∈Rd\vec y \in \mathbb{R}^dy​∈Rd,

sup⁡x⃗∈S{<x⃗,y⃗>}=∥y⃗∥q. \sup_{ \vec x \in S } \Big\{ \left< \vec x, \vec y \right> \Big\} = \Vert \vec y \Vert_q. x∈Ssup​{⟨x,y​⟩}=∥y​∥q​.

Consider

max⁡<x⃗,y⃗> s.t., ∥x⃗∥S=1. \max \left< \vec x, \vec y \right> \, s.t., \, \Vert \vec x \Vert_S = 1. max⟨x,y​⟩s.t.,∥x∥S​=1.

Define

f(x⃗,λ)=<x⃗,y⃗>−λ(∥x⃗∥p−1). f(\vec x, \lambda) = \left< \vec x, \vec y \right> - \lambda( \Vert \vec x \Vert_p - 1). f(x,λ)=⟨x,y​⟩−λ(∥x∥p​−1).

WLOG, assume that y⃗≥0\vec y \ge 0y​≥0. Then x⃗≥0\vec x \ge 0x≥0. Setting

∂f∂xi=yi−λpxip−1(∑j∈[d]xip)1−1/p=0. \frac{\partial f}{ \partial x_i} = y_i - \lambda \frac{ p x_i^{ p - 1 } }{ \Big( \sum_{ j \in [d] } x_i^p \Big)^{ 1 - 1 / p} } = 0. ∂xi​∂f​=yi​−λ(∑j∈[d]​xip​)1−1/ppxip−1​​=0.

As ∥x⃗∥p=1\Vert \vec x \Vert_p = 1∥x∥p​=1 and 1/q=(p−1)/p1 / q = (p - 1) / p1/q=(p−1)/p, we have

xi=(yiλp)1/(p−1)=(yiλp)q/p,∥x⃗∥pp=1(λp)q∑i∈[d]yiq=1. \begin{aligned} x_i &= \left( \frac{ y_i }{ \lambda p} \right)^{1 / (p - 1)} = \left( \frac{ y_i }{ \lambda p} \right)^{ q / p} ,\\ \Vert \vec x \Vert_p^p &= \frac{1}{ (\lambda p)^q } \sum_{i \in [d] } y_i^q = 1. \end{aligned} xi​∥x∥pp​​=(λpyi​​)1/(p−1)=(λpyi​​)q/p,=(λp)q1​i∈[d]∑​yiq​=1.​

Finally,

<x⃗,y⃗>=1(λp)q/p∑j∈[d]yiq/p+1=1(λp)q/p∑j∈[d]yiq=(∑j∈[d]yiq)1−1p=∥y⃗∥q. \begin{aligned} \left< \vec x, \vec y \right> &= \frac{1}{ (\lambda p)^{ q / p} } \sum_{j \in [d] } y_i^{ q / p + 1 } \\ &= \frac{1}{ (\lambda p)^{ q / p} } \sum_{j \in [d] } y_i^{ q } \\ &= \left( \sum_{j \in [d] } y_i^{ q } \right)^{ 1 - \frac{1}{p} } \\ &= \Vert \vec y \Vert_q. \end{aligned} ⟨x,y​⟩​=(λp)q/p1​j∈[d]∑​yiq/p+1​=(λp)q/p1​j∈[d]∑​yiq​=⎝⎛​j∈[d]∑​yiq​⎠⎞​1−p1​=∥y​∥q​.​

□\square□

The following fact provides geometric interpretation of Holder Inequality.

Fact (Generalized Holder Inequality).

<x⃗,y⃗>≤∥x⃗∥S⋅∥y⃗∥S∗ \left< \vec x, \vec y \right> \le \Vert \vec x \Vert_S \cdot \Vert \vec y \Vert_{S^*} ⟨x,y​⟩≤∥x∥S​⋅∥y​∥S∗​

Proof. If ∥x⃗∥S≤1\Vert \vec x \Vert_S \le 1∥x∥S​≤1, then x⃗∈S\vec x \in Sx∈S. Hence,

∥y⃗∥S∗≐sup⁡v⃗∈S<v⃗,y⃗>≥<x⃗∥x⃗∥S,y⃗>. \Vert \vec y \Vert_{S^*} \doteq \sup_{ \vec v \in S } \left< \vec v, \vec y \right> \ge \left< \frac{\vec x}{ \Vert \vec x \Vert_S }, \vec y \right>. ∥y​∥S∗​≐v∈Ssup​⟨v,y​⟩≥⟨∥x∥S​x​,y​⟩.

We can also see that if ∥x⃗∥S=1\Vert \vec x \Vert_S = 1∥x∥S​=1 and ∥y⃗∥S∗=1\Vert \vec y \Vert_{S^*} = 1∥y​∥S∗​=1, then

<x⃗,y⃗>≤1. \left< \vec x, \vec y \right> \le 1. ⟨x,y​⟩≤1.

This is trivially true by the definition of S∗S^*S∗.

□\square□

Reference

[1] Ryan Tibshirani, 10-725/36-725: Convex Optimization Fall 2018, Lecture 13: Duality: Uses and Correspondences.
[2] A.A. Ahmadi, ORF 523 Lecture 2 Spring 2016.

Azuma-Hoeffding Inequality

Posted on 2021-06-02 Edited on 2021-11-16

Azuma-Hoeffding Inequality

Let X0,…,XnX_0, \ldots, X_nX0​,…,Xn​ be a martingale such that

Ak≤Xk−Xk−1≤Bk A_k \le X_k - X_{k - 1} \le B_k Ak​≤Xk​−Xk−1​≤Bk​

for some random variables AkA_kAk​ and BkB_kBk​ that may be functions of X0,X1,…Xk−1X_0, X_1, \ldots X_{k - 1}X0​,X1​,…Xk−1​. If Bk−Ak≤ckB_k - A_k \le c_kBk​−Ak​≤ck​ for some constants ckc_kck​, then, for all t≥0t \ge 0t≥0 and any η>0\eta > 0η>0,

Pr⁡[∣Xt−X0∣≥η]≤2exp⁡(−2η2∑k∈[t]ck2) \Pr[ | X_t - X_0 | \ge \eta ] \le 2 \exp \left( - \frac{ 2 \eta^2 }{ \sum_{ k \in [t] } c_k^2 }\right) Pr[∣Xt​−X0​∣≥η]≤2exp(−∑k∈[t]​ck2​2η2​)

Hoeffding’s Lemma

Let XXX be any real-valued random variable with mean 000, such that a≤X≤b{\displaystyle a\leq X\leq b}a≤X≤b almost surely, i.e. with probability one. Then, for all λ∈R{\displaystyle \lambda \in \mathbb {R} }λ∈R,

E[eλX]≤exp⁡(λ2(b−a)28). {\displaystyle \mathbb {E} \left[ e^{\lambda X} \right] \le \exp {\Big (} {\frac{\lambda^{2}(b-a)^{2}} {8}} {\Big ) }. } E[eλX]≤exp(8λ2(b−a)2​).

Proof. We prove a version with a weaker factor of 12\frac{1}{2}21​ but simpler analysis. The proof for the stronger version is included in the appendix.

First, consider a special case of Rademacher random variable σ\sigmaσ that equals −1-1−1 and 111 with equal probability. For all λ∈R\lambda \in \mathbb{R}λ∈R,

E[eλσ]=e−λ+eλ2=∑i≥0λ2i(2i)!≤∑i≥0(λ2/2)ii!=eλ2/2. \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E} [ e^{ \lambda \sigma} ] &= \frac{ e^{ - \lambda } + e^{ \lambda } }{ 2 } &= \sum_{ i \ge 0 } \frac{ \lambda^{ 2i } }{ (2i)! } &\le \sum_{ i \ge 0 } \frac{ ( \lambda^2 / 2)^i }{ i ! } &= e^{ \lambda^2 / 2}. \end{aligned} E[eλσ]​=2e−λ+eλ​​=i≥0∑​(2i)!λ2i​​≤i≥0∑​i!(λ2/2)i​​=eλ2/2.​

Next, let YYY be identical copy of XXX. By Jensen’s inequality,

E[eλX]=E[eλ(X−E[X])]=EX[eλ(X−EY[Y])]≤EX,Y[eλ(X−Y)] \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E} [ e^{ \lambda X }] &= \mathbb{E} [ e^{ \lambda ( X - \mathbb{E}[ X ] ) }] &= \mathbb{E}_{X} [ e^{ \lambda ( X - \mathbb{E}_{Y} [ Y ] ) }] &\le \mathbb{E}_{ X, Y } [ e^{ \lambda ( X - Y ) }] \end{aligned} E[eλX]​=E[eλ(X−E[X])]​=EX​[eλ(X−EY​[Y])]​≤EX,Y​[eλ(X−Y)]​

Since XXX and YYY has identical distribution, the random variable σ(X−Y)\sigma( X - Y)σ(X−Y) has the same distribution as X−YX - YX−Y. Hence,

EX,Y[eλ(X−Y)]=EX,Y[Eσ[eλ(X−Y)σ|X,Y]]. \mathbb{E}_{ X, Y } [ e^{ \lambda ( X - Y ) }] = \mathbb{E}_{ X, Y } \left[ \mathbb{E}_\sigma [ e^{ \lambda ( X - Y ) \sigma } \middle\vert X, Y] \right]. EX,Y​[eλ(X−Y)]=EX,Y​[Eσ​[eλ(X−Y)σ∣∣∣∣​X,Y]].

Finally, by previous argument,

Eσ[eλ(X−Y)σ∣X,Y]≤eλ2(X−Y)2/2≤eλ2(b−a)2/2. \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_{\sigma } [ e^{ \lambda ( X - Y ) \sigma } \mid X, Y ] \le e^{ \lambda^2 ( X - Y )^2 / 2 } \le e^{ \lambda^2 (b - a)^2 / 2 }. \end{aligned} Eσ​[eλ(X−Y)σ∣X,Y]≤eλ2(X−Y)2/2≤eλ2(b−a)2/2.​

It concludes that EX,Y[eλ(X−Y)]≤eλ2(b−a)2/2\mathbb{E}_{ X, Y } [ e^{ \lambda ( X - Y ) }] \le e^{ \lambda^2 (b - a)^2 / 2 }EX,Y​[eλ(X−Y)]≤eλ2(b−a)2/2.

□\square□

Proof of the Theorem

Define Zk=Xk−Xk−1Z_k = X_k - X_{k - 1}Zk​=Xk​−Xk−1​ for each k∈[n]k \in [n]k∈[n]. Since X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ is a martingale,

E[Zk∣X0,…,Xk−1]=0. \mathbb{E}[ Z_k \mid X_0, \ldots, X_{k - 1} ] = 0. E[Zk​∣X0​,…,Xk−1​]=0.

Via Hoeffding’s Lemma, for each k∈[n]k \in [n]k∈[n], and for all λ∈R\lambda \in \mathbb{R}λ∈R, it holds that

E[eλZt]≤eλ2ck2/8. \mathbb{E} \left[ e^{\lambda Z_t } \right] \le e^{ \lambda^2 c_k^2 / 8 }. E[eλZt​]≤eλ2ck2​/8.

It follows that

E[eλ∑k∈[t]Zk]=E[E[eλ∑k∈[t]Zk|Z1,…,Zt−1]]=E[E[eλZt]⋅E[eλ∑k∈[t−1]Zk|Z1,…,Zt−1]]≤eλ2ct2/8⋅E[E[eλ∑k∈[t−1]Zk|Z1,…,Zt−1]] \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E} \left[ e^{ \lambda \sum_{k \in [t]} Z_k } \right] &=\mathbb{E} \left[ \mathbb{E} \left[ e^{ \lambda \sum_{k \in [t] } Z_k } \middle\vert Z_1, \ldots, Z_{t - 1} \right] \right] \\ &=\mathbb{E} \left[ \mathbb{E} \left[ e^{\lambda Z_t } \right] \cdot \mathbb{E} \left[ e^{ \lambda \sum_{k \in [t - 1] } Z_k } \middle\vert Z_1, \ldots, Z_{t - 1} \right] \right] \\ &\le e^{ \lambda^2 c_t^2 / 8 } \cdot \mathbb{E} \left[ \mathbb{E} \left[ e^{ \lambda \sum_{k \in [t - 1] } Z_k } \middle\vert Z_1, \ldots, Z_{t - 1} \right] \right] \end{aligned} E[eλ∑k∈[t]​Zk​]​=E[E[eλ∑k∈[t]​Zk​∣∣∣∣​Z1​,…,Zt−1​]]=E[E[eλZt​]⋅E[eλ∑k∈[t−1]​Zk​∣∣∣∣​Z1​,…,Zt−1​]]≤eλ2ct2​/8⋅E[E[eλ∑k∈[t−1]​Zk​∣∣∣∣​Z1​,…,Zt−1​]]​

By induction, it holds that

E[eλ∑k∈[t]Zk]≤eλ2∑k∈[t]ck2/8. \mathbb{E} \left[ e^{ \lambda \sum_{k \in [t]} Z_k } \right] \le e^{ \lambda^2 \sum_{k \in [t] } c_k^2 / 8 }. E[eλ∑k∈[t]​Zk​]≤eλ2∑k∈[t]​ck2​/8.

For all λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0, via Markov’s inequality,

Pr⁡[∑k∈[t]Zk≥η]=Pr⁡[eλ∑k∈[t]Zk≥eλη]≤E[eλ∑k∈[t]Zk]E[eλη]≤eλ2∑k∈[t]ck2/8−λη. \begin{aligned} \Pr \left[ \sum_{k \in [t] } Z_k \ge \eta \right] &= \Pr \left[ e^{ \lambda \sum_{k \in [t] } Z_k } \ge e^{ \lambda \eta } \right] \\ &\le \frac{ \mathbb{E} \left[ e^{ \lambda \sum_{k \in [t]} Z_k } \right] }{ \mathbb{E}[ e^{ \lambda \eta } ] } \\ &\le e^{ \lambda^2 \sum_{k \in [t] } c_k^2 / 8 - \lambda \eta }. \end{aligned} Pr⎣⎢⎡​k∈[t]∑​Zk​≥η⎦⎥⎤​​=Pr[eλ∑k∈[t]​Zk​≥eλη]≤E[eλη]E[eλ∑k∈[t]​Zk​]​≤eλ2∑k∈[t]​ck2​/8−λη.​

When λ=4η∑k∈[t]ck2\lambda = \frac{4 \eta}{ \sum_{k \in [t] } c_k^2 }λ=∑k∈[t]​ck2​4η​, the probability is minimized to

exp⁡{2η2∑k∈[t]ck2−4η2∑k∈[t]ck2}=exp⁡{−2η2∑k∈[t]ck2}. \exp \left\{ \frac{2 \eta^2 }{ \sum_{k \in [t] } c_k^2 } - \frac{4 \eta^2 }{ \sum_{k \in [t] } c_k^2 } \right\} = \exp \left\{ - \frac{2 \eta^2 }{ \sum_{k \in [t] } c_k^2 } \right\}. exp{∑k∈[t]​ck2​2η2​−∑k∈[t]​ck2​4η2​}=exp{−∑k∈[t]​ck2​2η2​}.

□\square□

Hoeffding’s Lemma

Proof 1

Suppose that b≠ab \neq ab=a (otherwise, XXX is a constant). Define

  1. θ=−ab−a=1−bb−a∈(0,1)\theta = - \frac{a}{b - a} = 1 - \frac{b}{b - a} \in (0, 1)θ=−b−aa​=1−b−ab​∈(0,1);
  2. c=(b−a)>0c = (b - a) > 0c=(b−a)>0.

By Jensen’s inequality,

E[eλX]=E[exp⁡(b−Xb−a⋅λa+X−ab−a⋅λb)]≤E[b−Xb−a⋅exp⁡(λa)+X−ab−a⋅exp⁡(λb)]=(1−θ)⋅exp⁡(λa)+θ⋅exp⁡(λb)=(1−θ+θeλ(b−a))exp⁡(λa)=(1−θ+θe(λc))e−θ(λc) \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E} [ e^{\lambda X } ] &= \mathbb{E} \left[ \exp \left( \frac{b - X}{ b - a} \cdot \lambda a + \frac{X - a}{b - a} \cdot \lambda b \right) \right] \\ &\le \mathbb{E} \left[ \frac{b - X}{ b - a} \cdot \exp \left( \lambda a \right) + \frac{X - a}{b - a} \cdot \exp \left( \lambda b \right) \right] \\ &= (1 - \theta) \cdot \exp \left( \lambda a \right) + \theta \cdot \exp \left( \lambda b \right) \\ &= \left( 1 - \theta + \theta e^{\lambda (b - a)} \right) \exp \left( \lambda a \right) \\ &= \left( 1 - \theta + \theta e^{ (\lambda c) } \right) e^ { - \theta (\lambda c) } \end{aligned} E[eλX]​=E[exp(b−ab−X​⋅λa+b−aX−a​⋅λb)]≤E[b−ab−X​⋅exp(λa)+b−aX−a​⋅exp(λb)]=(1−θ)⋅exp(λa)+θ⋅exp(λb)=(1−θ+θeλ(b−a))exp(λa)=(1−θ+θe(λc))e−θ(λc)​

Let f(z)≐−θz+ln⁡(1−θ+θez)f(z) \doteq - \theta z + \ln \left( 1 - \theta + \theta e^{ z} \right)f(z)≐−θz+ln(1−θ+θez).
The function is well-defined, as 1−θ+θez>01 - \theta + \theta e^{ z} > 01−θ+θez>0 for z∈Rz \in \mathbb{R}z∈R.
Observe that

exp⁡{f(λc)}=(1−θ+θeλc)exp⁡(−λθc). \exp \Big \{ f(\lambda c) \Big \} = \left( 1 - \theta + \theta e^{\lambda c } \right) \exp \left( - \lambda \theta c \right). exp{f(λc)}=(1−θ+θeλc)exp(−λθc).

Further,

f′(z)=−θ+θez1−θ+θez, f'(z) = - \theta + \frac{ \theta e^{ z} }{ 1 - \theta + \theta e^{ z} }, f′(z)=−θ+1−θ+θezθez​,

and

f′′(z)=θez(1−θ+θez)−(θez)2(1−θ+θez)2=(1−θ)θez(1−θ+θez)2≤14. f''(z) = \frac{ \theta e^{ z} ( 1 - \theta + \theta e^{ z} ) - ( \theta e^z )^2 }{ ( 1 - \theta + \theta e^{ z} )^2 } = \frac{ ( 1 - \theta ) \theta e^{ z} }{ ( 1 - \theta + \theta e^{ z} )^2 } \le \frac{1}{4}. f′′(z)=(1−θ+θez)2θez(1−θ+θez)−(θez)2​=(1−θ+θez)2(1−θ)θez​≤41​.

Finally, by Taylor’s expansion, there exists some z∗∈[0,λc]z^* \in [0, \lambda c]z∗∈[0,λc], such that

f(λc)=f(0)+f′(0)⋅(λc)+f′′(z∗)2(λc)2=f′′(z∗)2(λc)2≤18(λc)2=λ2(b−a)28. \begin{aligned} f(\lambda c) &= f(0) + f' (0) \cdot (\lambda c) + \frac{ f''(z^*) }{ 2 } (\lambda c)^2 \\ &= \frac{ f''(z^*) }{ 2 } (\lambda c)^2 \\ &\le \frac{1}{8 } (\lambda c)^2 \\ &= \frac{ \lambda^2 (b - a)^2 }{8 }. \end{aligned} f(λc)​=f(0)+f′(0)⋅(λc)+2f′′(z∗)​(λc)2=2f′′(z∗)​(λc)2≤81​(λc)2=8λ2(b−a)2​.​

The picture above shows that the bound might not be tight.

□\square□

Proof 2

Preliminaries

The proof relies on the following lemma.

Lemma. Let (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,P) be a probability space.
Let YYY be a nonnegative F\mathcal{F}F-measurable function, and define the measure μ\muμ by

μ(A)≐∫AY d P,A∈F. \mu(A) \doteq \int_A Y \, d\,\mathbb{P}, \qquad A \in \mathcal{F}. μ(A)≐∫A​YdP,A∈F.

Then for nonnegative F\mathcal{F}F-measurable function ZZZ, it holds that

∫Z d μ=∫Z⋅Y d P. \int Z \, d\, \mu = \int Z \cdot Y \, d\, \mathbb{P}. ∫Zdμ=∫Z⋅YdP.

Proof of the Lemma. If ZZZ is an indicator function 1A1_A1A​ for some A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F, then the lemma clearly holds. It follows that the lemma holds for nonnegative simple functions. For general nonnegative ZZZ, there is a sequence of nonnegative simple functions {Zn}\{ Z_n \}{Zn​}, such that Zn↑ZZ_n \uparrow ZZn​↑Z. Via monotone convergence theorem, we obtain

lim⁡n∫Zn d μ=∫Z d μ,lim⁡n∫Zn⋅Y d P=∫Z⋅Y d P. \lim_n \int Z_n \, d\, \mu = \int Z \, d\, \mu, \\ \lim_n \int Z_n \cdot Y \, d\, \mathbb{P} = \int Z \cdot Y \, d\, \mathbb{P}. nlim​∫Zn​dμ=∫Zdμ,nlim​∫Zn​⋅YdP=∫Z⋅YdP.

■\blacksquare■

Formal Proof

Let XXX be a random variable such that a≤X≤ba \le X \le ba≤X≤b.
Define the function f:R≥0→Rf: \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:R≥0​→R as

f(λ)=E[exp⁡(λX)],  f(\lambda) = \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)],\, f(λ)=E[exp(λX)],

and let

h(λ)=ln⁡f(λ). h(\lambda) = \ln f(\lambda). h(λ)=lnf(λ).

We will justify the interchange of differentiation and expectation, and show that

f′(λ)=E[Xexp⁡(λX)], f′′(λ)=E[X2exp⁡(λX)]. f'(\lambda) = \mathbb{E}\left[ X \exp ( \lambda X) \right],\, \\ f''(\lambda) = \mathbb{E}\left[ X^2 \exp ( \lambda X) \right]. f′(λ)=E[Xexp(λX)],f′′(λ)=E[X2exp(λX)].

Therefore,

h′(λ)=f′(λ)f(λ)=E[Xexp⁡(λX)]E[exp⁡(λX)] ,h′′(λ)=f′′(λ)⋅f(λ)−(f′(λ))2(f(λ))2=E[X2exp⁡(λX)]⋅E[exp⁡(λX)]−(E[Xexp⁡(λX)])2(E[exp⁡(λX)])2=E[X2exp⁡(λX)]E[exp⁡(λX)]−(E[Xexp⁡(λX)])2(E[exp⁡(λX)])2. \begin{aligned} h'(\lambda) &= \frac{ f'(\lambda) }{ f(\lambda) } = \frac{ \mathbb{E}\left[ X \exp ( \lambda X) \right] }{ \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)] }\,, \\ h''(\lambda) &= \frac{ f''(\lambda) \cdot f(\lambda) - \left( f'(\lambda) \right)^2 }{ \left( f(\lambda) \right)^2 } \\ &= \frac{ \mathbb{E}[X^2 \exp(\lambda X)] \cdot \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)] - \left( \mathbb{E}[ X \exp(\lambda X)] \right)^2 }{ \left( \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)] \right)^2 } \\ &= \frac{ \mathbb{E}[X^2 \exp(\lambda X)] }{ \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)] } - \frac{ \left( \mathbb{E}[ X \exp(\lambda X)] \right)^2 }{ \left( \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)] \right)^2 }. \end{aligned} h′(λ)h′′(λ)​=f(λ)f′(λ)​=E[exp(λX)]E[Xexp(λX)]​,=(f(λ))2f′′(λ)⋅f(λ)−(f′(λ))2​=(E[exp(λX)])2E[X2exp(λX)]⋅E[exp(λX)]−(E[Xexp(λX)])2​=E[exp(λX)]E[X2exp(λX)]​−(E[exp(λX)])2(E[Xexp(λX)])2​.​

Suppose (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,P) is the probability space on which XXX is defined, i.e., XXX is a function from F\mathcal{F}F to R\mathbb{R}R.
Now we define a new measure Pλ:F→R\mathbb{P}_\lambda: \mathcal{F} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}Pλ​:F→R as

Pλ(A)≐∫Aexp⁡(λX)E[exp⁡(λX)] dP,∀A∈F. \mathbb{P}_{\lambda}(A) \doteq \int_A \frac{\exp(\lambda X)}{ \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)] } \, d \mathbb{P}, \quad \forall A \in \mathcal{F}. Pλ​(A)≐∫A​E[exp(λX)]exp(λX)​dP,∀A∈F.

It is easy to see that Pλ\mathbb{P}_{\lambda}Pλ​ is a new probability measure.
The function δ(λ)≐exp⁡(λX)E[exp⁡(λX)]\delta(\lambda) \doteq \frac{\exp(\lambda X)}{ \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)] }δ(λ)≐E[exp(λX)]exp(λX)​ is called the density function of Pλ\mathbb{P}_{\lambda}Pλ​.
We see that

Eλ[X]≐∫XdPλ=∫Xexp⁡(λX)E[exp⁡(λX)] dP=E[Xexp⁡(λX)]E[exp⁡(λX)] ,Eλ[X2]≐∫X2dPλ=∫X2exp⁡(λX)E[exp⁡(λX)] dP=E[X2exp⁡(λX)]E[exp⁡(λX)] . \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_{\lambda} [X] \doteq \int X d { \mathbb{P}_{\lambda} } &= \int X \frac{\exp(\lambda X)}{ \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)] } \, d \mathbb{P} = \frac{ \mathbb{E}\left[ X \exp ( \lambda X) \right] }{ \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)] }\,, \\ \mathbb{E}_{\lambda} [X^2] \doteq \int X^2 d { \mathbb{P}_{\lambda} } &= \int X^2 \frac{\exp(\lambda X)}{ \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)] } \, d \mathbb{P} = \frac{ \mathbb{E}\left[ X^2 \exp ( \lambda X) \right] }{ \mathbb{E}[\exp(\lambda X)] }\,. \end{aligned} Eλ​[X]≐∫XdPλ​Eλ​[X2]≐∫X2dPλ​​=∫XE[exp(λX)]exp(λX)​dP=E[exp(λX)]E[Xexp(λX)]​,=∫X2E[exp(λX)]exp(λX)​dP=E[exp(λX)]E[X2exp(λX)]​.​

It follows that

h′′(λ)=Varλ[X]≐Eλ[X2]−(Eλ[X])2. \begin{aligned} h''(\lambda) =\mathbb{Var}_{\lambda} [ X ] \doteq \mathbb{E}_{\lambda} [X^2] - \big( \mathbb{E}_{\lambda} [X] \big)^2. \end{aligned} h′′(λ)=Varλ​[X]≐Eλ​[X2]−(Eλ​[X])2.​

Therefore,

Varλ[X]=Varλ[X−a+b2]=Eλ[(X−a+b2)2]≤(b−a)24. \mathbb{Var}_{\lambda} [ X ] = \mathbb{Var}_{\lambda} \left[ X - \frac{a + b}{2} \right] = \mathbb{E}_{\lambda} \left[ \left( X - \frac{a + b}{2} \right)^2 \right] \le \frac{(b - a)^2}{4}. Varλ​[X]=Varλ​[X−2a+b​]=Eλ​[(X−2a+b​)2]≤4(b−a)2​.

Finally, via Taylor’s expansion,

h(λ)=h(0)+λ⋅h′(0)+λ22h′′(λ∗). h(\lambda) = h(0) + \lambda \cdot h'(0) + \frac{\lambda^2}{2} h''(\lambda^*). h(λ)=h(0)+λ⋅h′(0)+2λ2​h′′(λ∗).

Since h(0)=0h(0) = 0h(0)=0, h′(0)=E[X]=0h'(0) = \mathbb{E}[X] = 0h′(0)=E[X]=0, and h′′(λ∗)=Varλ∗[X]≤(b−a)2/4h''(\lambda^*) = \mathbb{Var}_{\lambda^*}[X] \le (b - a)^2 / 4h′′(λ∗)=Varλ∗​[X]≤(b−a)2/4, we conclude that

h(λ)≤(b−a)28. h(\lambda) \le \frac{ (b - a)^2 }{ 8 }. h(λ)≤8(b−a)2​.

First Derivative of fff.

Denote M≐max⁡{∣a∣,∣b∣}M \doteq \max\{ |a|, |b| \}M≐max{∣a∣,∣b∣}.
For each n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}_+n∈N+​,

g(n)≐f(λ+1/n)−f(λ)1/n=E[exp⁡((λ+1/n)⋅X)−exp⁡(λX)1/n] g(n) \doteq \frac{ f(\lambda + 1 / n) - f(\lambda) }{ 1 / n} = \mathbb{E}\left[ \frac{ \exp( (\lambda + 1 / n) \cdot X) - \exp(\lambda X) }{ 1 / n} \right] g(n)≐1/nf(λ+1/n)−f(λ)​=E[1/nexp((λ+1/n)⋅X)−exp(λX)​]

Via mean value theorem, there exists λ′∈[λ,λ+1/n]\lambda' \in [\lambda, \lambda + 1 / n]λ′∈[λ,λ+1/n], s.t.,

exp⁡((λ+1/n)⋅X)−exp⁡(λX)1/n=X⋅exp⁡(λ′⋅X)≤M⋅exp⁡((λ+1)⋅M). \frac{ \exp( (\lambda + 1 / n) \cdot X) - \exp(\lambda X) }{ 1 / n} = X \cdot \exp ( \lambda' \cdot X) \le M \cdot \exp( (\lambda + 1) \cdot M). 1/nexp((λ+1/n)⋅X)−exp(λX)​=X⋅exp(λ′⋅X)≤M⋅exp((λ+1)⋅M).

Since the RHS is integrable, via dominated convergence theorem,

f′(λ)=lim⁡ng(n)=E[lim⁡nexp⁡((λ+1/n)⋅X)−exp⁡(λX)1/n]=E[Xexp⁡(λX)]. f'(\lambda) = \lim_n g(n) = \mathbb{E}\left[ \lim_n \frac{ \exp( (\lambda + 1 / n) \cdot X) - \exp(\lambda X) }{ 1 / n} \right] = \mathbb{E}\left[ X \exp ( \lambda X) \right] . f′(λ)=nlim​g(n)=E[nlim​1/nexp((λ+1/n)⋅X)−exp(λX)​]=E[Xexp(λX)].

Second Derivative of fff.

Similarly, for each n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N, there exists λ′∈[λ,λ+1/n]\lambda' \in [\lambda, \lambda + 1 / n]λ′∈[λ,λ+1/n], s.t.,

X⋅exp⁡((λ+1/n)⋅X)−X⋅exp⁡(λX)1/n=X2⋅exp⁡(λ′⋅X)≤M2⋅exp⁡((λ+1)⋅M). \frac{ X \cdot \exp( (\lambda + 1 / n) \cdot X) - X \cdot \exp(\lambda X) }{ 1 / n} = X^2 \cdot \exp ( \lambda' \cdot X) \le M^2 \cdot \exp( (\lambda + 1) \cdot M). 1/nX⋅exp((λ+1/n)⋅X)−X⋅exp(λX)​=X2⋅exp(λ′⋅X)≤M2⋅exp((λ+1)⋅M).

It follows via dominated convergence theorem that

f′′(λ)=lim⁡nE[X⋅exp⁡((λ+1/n)⋅X)−X⋅exp⁡(λX)1/n]=E[lim⁡nX⋅exp⁡((λ+1/n)⋅X)−X⋅exp⁡(λX)1/n]=E[X2exp⁡(λX)]. \begin{aligned} f''(\lambda) &= \lim_n \mathbb{E}\left[ \frac{ X \cdot \exp( (\lambda + 1 / n) \cdot X) - X \cdot \exp(\lambda X) }{ 1 / n} \right] \\ &= \mathbb{E}\left[ \lim_n \frac{ X \cdot \exp( (\lambda + 1 / n) \cdot X) - X \cdot \exp(\lambda X) }{ 1 / n} \right] \\ &= \mathbb{E}\left[ X^2 \exp ( \lambda X) \right] . \end{aligned} f′′(λ)​=nlim​E[1/nX⋅exp((λ+1/n)⋅X)−X⋅exp(λX)​]=E[nlim​1/nX⋅exp((λ+1/n)⋅X)−X⋅exp(λX)​]=E[X2exp(λX)].​

□\square□

AMS Sketch For Inner Product Estimation

Posted on 2021-05-21

Problem

Let x⃗=(x1,...,xn)\vec x = (x_1, ..., x_n)x=(x1​,...,xn​), y⃗=(y1,...,yn)∈Rn\vec y = (y_1, ..., y_n) \in \mathbb{R}^ny​=(y1​,...,yn​)∈Rn. Given δ∈(0,1)\delta \in (0, 1)δ∈(0,1), construct a data structure with space usage O(1ϵ2log⁡1δ)O \left( \frac{1}{\epsilon^2} \log \frac{1}{\delta} \right)O(ϵ21​logδ1​), such that with failure probability at most δ∈(0,1)\delta \in (0, 1)δ∈(0,1),

  • it returns an estimate of the inner product <x⃗,y⃗>\left< \vec x, \vec y \right>⟨x,y​⟩ with error O(ϵ⋅∥x⃗∥2⋅∥y⃗∥2)O( \epsilon \cdot \Vert \vec x \Vert_2 \cdot \Vert \vec y \Vert_2 )O(ϵ⋅∥x∥2​⋅∥y​∥2​).

Remark: If we have x⃗=y⃗\vec x = \vec yx=y​, we get an estimator of ∥x⃗∥22\Vert \vec x \Vert_2^2∥x∥22​ with ϵ\epsilonϵ-relative error.

Prototype

Let σ⃗=(σ1,...,σn)∈{−1,1}n\vec \sigma = (\sigma_1, ..., \sigma_n) \in \{ - 1, 1 \}^nσ=(σ1​,...,σn​)∈{−1,1}n a sequence of nnn independent Rademachers.

Define

X≐<x⃗,σ⃗>,Y≐<y⃗,σ⃗>. X \doteq \left< \vec x, \vec \sigma \right>, \qquad Y \doteq \left< \vec y, \vec \sigma \right>. X≐⟨x,σ⟩,Y≐⟨y​,σ⟩.

Theorem. X⋅YX \cdot YX⋅Y is an unbiased estimator of <x⃗,y⃗>\left< \vec x, \vec y \right>⟨x,y​⟩.

Proof.
Observe ∀i,j∈[n]\forall i, j \in [n]∀i,j∈[n], if entries of σ\sigmaσ are pairwise independent, then

E[σiσj]={1,i=j0,i≠j. \mathbb{E} [ \sigma_i \sigma_j ] = \begin{cases} 1, & i = j \\ 0, & i \neq j \end{cases}. E[σi​σj​]={1,0,​i=ji=j​.

Hence,

E[X⋅Y]=E[(∑i∈[n]σixi)(∑j∈[n]σjyj)]=∑i,j∈[n]E[σiσj]xiyj=∑i∈[n]xiyi. \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E} [ X \cdot Y ] &= \mathbb{E} \left[ \left( \sum_{i \in [n] } \sigma_i x_i \right) \left( \sum_{j \in [n] } \sigma_j y_j \right) \right] \\ &= \sum_{i, j \in [n] } \mathbb{E} [ \sigma_i \sigma_j ]x_i y_j \\ &= \sum_{i \in [n] } x_i y_i. \end{aligned} E[X⋅Y]​=E⎣⎢⎡​⎝⎛​i∈[n]∑​σi​xi​⎠⎞​⎝⎛​j∈[n]∑​σj​yj​⎠⎞​⎦⎥⎤​=i,j∈[n]∑​E[σi​σj​]xi​yj​=i∈[n]∑​xi​yi​.​

□\square□

Theorem. Var[X⋅Y]≤∥x⃗∥22⋅∥y⃗∥22\mathbb{Var}[ X \cdot Y ] \le \Vert \vec x \Vert_2^2 \cdot \Vert \vec y \Vert_2^2Var[X⋅Y]≤∥x∥22​⋅∥y​∥22​.

Proof. If entries of σ\sigmaσ are four-wise independent, then

Var[X⋅Y]=Var[(∑i∈[n]σixi)(∑j∈[n]σjyj)]=Var[∑i≠j∈[n]σiσjxiyj]=∑i≠jVar[σiσjxiyj]+∑i≠j,k≠ℓ,(i,j)≠(k,ℓ)Cov[σiσjxiyj,σkσℓxkyℓ]=∑i≠jxi2yj2≤∥x⃗∥22⋅∥y⃗∥22 \begin{aligned} \mathbb{Var} [ X \cdot Y ] &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \left( \sum_{i \in [n] } \sigma_i x_i \right) \left( \sum_{j \in [n] } \sigma_j y_j \right) \right] \\ &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{i \neq j \in [n] } \sigma_i \sigma_j x_i y_j \right] \\ &= \sum_{i \neq j } \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sigma_i \sigma_j x_i y_j \right] + \sum_{i \neq j, k \neq \ell, (i, j) \neq (k, \ell) } \mathbb{Cov} [ \sigma_i \sigma_j x_i y_j, \sigma_k \sigma_\ell x_k y_\ell ]\\ &= \sum_{i \neq j } x_i^2 y_j^2 \\ &\le \Vert \vec x \Vert_2^2 \cdot \Vert \vec y \Vert_2^2 \end{aligned} Var[X⋅Y]​=Var⎣⎢⎡​⎝⎛​i∈[n]∑​σi​xi​⎠⎞​⎝⎛​j∈[n]∑​σj​yj​⎠⎞​⎦⎥⎤​=Var⎣⎢⎡​i=j∈[n]∑​σi​σj​xi​yj​⎦⎥⎤​=i=j∑​Var[σi​σj​xi​yj​]+i=j,k=ℓ,(i,j)=(k,ℓ)∑​Cov[σi​σj​xi​yj​,σk​σℓ​xk​yℓ​]=i=j∑​xi2​yj2​≤∥x∥22​⋅∥y​∥22​​

□\square□

If we have mmm independent copies of XXX and YYY, denoted as X1,...,XmX_1, ..., X_mX1​,...,Xm​, and Y1,...,YmY_1, ..., Y_mY1​,...,Ym​, then we can compute the average (1/m)⋅∑i∈[m]Xi⋅Yi(1 / m) \cdot \sum_{i \in [m] } X_i \cdot Y_i(1/m)⋅∑i∈[m]​Xi​⋅Yi​, whose variance is bounded by (1/m)⋅∥x⃗∥22⋅∥y⃗∥22(1 / m) \cdot \Vert \vec x \Vert_2^2 \cdot \Vert \vec y \Vert_2^2(1/m)⋅∥x∥22​⋅∥y​∥22​. If we set m=1/ϵ2m = 1 / \epsilon^2m=1/ϵ2, then it becomes ϵ2⋅∥x⃗∥22⋅∥y⃗∥22\epsilon^2 \cdot \Vert \vec x \Vert_2^2 \cdot \Vert \vec y \Vert_2^2ϵ2⋅∥x∥22​⋅∥y​∥22​ and by Chebyshev’s inequality ∣(1/m)⋅∑i∈[m]Xi⋅Yi−<x⃗,y⃗>∣|(1 / m) \cdot \sum_{i \in [m] } X_i \cdot Y_i - \left< \vec x , \vec y \right> |∣(1/m)⋅∑i∈[m]​Xi​⋅Yi​−⟨x,y​⟩∣ is bounded by ϵ⋅∥x⃗∥2⋅∥y⃗∥2\epsilon \cdot \Vert \vec x \Vert_2 \cdot \Vert \vec y \Vert_2ϵ⋅∥x∥2​⋅∥y​∥2​ with constant probability.

By Chernoff bound, we can boost the probability to 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ, by repeating the experiment O(log⁡1δ)O(\log \frac{1}{\delta})O(logδ1​) times and taking the median of the estimation.

Computing (1/m)⋅∑i∈[m]Xi⋅Yi(1 / m) \cdot \sum_{i \in [m] } X_i \cdot Y_i(1/m)⋅∑i∈[m]​Xi​⋅Yi​ takes O(1/ϵ2)O( 1 / \epsilon^2 )O(1/ϵ2) time. Repeating this O(log⁡1δ)O(\log \frac{1}{ \delta})O(logδ1​) times and taking the median results in time complexity O(log⁡(1/δ)ϵ2)O( \frac{\log (1 / \delta) }{\epsilon^2} )O(ϵ2log(1/δ)​).

On the other hand, we construct O(ϵ2⋅log⁡1δ)O ( \epsilon^2 \cdot \log \frac{1}{\delta} )O(ϵ2⋅logδ1​) copies of XXX, which takes time

O(n⋅ϵ2⋅log⁡1δ). O ( n \cdot \epsilon^2 \cdot \log \frac{1}{\delta} ). O(n⋅ϵ2⋅logδ1​).

Algorithm

In this section, we show how to reduce the construction time to

O(n⋅log⁡1δ). O ( n \cdot \log \frac{1}{\delta} ). O(n⋅logδ1​).

Given m∈N+m \in \mathbb{N}^+m∈N+, let h:[n]→[m]h : [n] \rightarrow [m]h:[n]→[m] be a pairwise independent hash function.

Let X⃗=(X1,...,Xm),Y⃗=(Y1,...,Ym)∈Rm\vec X = (X_1, ..., X_m), \vec Y = (Y_1, ..., Y_m) \in \mathbb{R}^mX=(X1​,...,Xm​),Y=(Y1​,...,Ym​)∈Rm be random vectors, such that ∀t∈[m]\forall t \in [m]∀t∈[m],

Xt=∑i∈[n]:h(i)=tσixi,Yt=∑i∈[n]:h(i)=tσiyi. X_t = \sum_{ i \in [n] : h(i) = t } \sigma_i x_i, \\ Y_t = \sum_{ i \in [n] : h(i) = t } \sigma_i y_i. Xt​=i∈[n]:h(i)=t∑​σi​xi​,Yt​=i∈[n]:h(i)=t∑​σi​yi​.

Theorem. <X⃗,Y⃗>\left< \vec X, \vec Y \right>⟨X,Y⟩ is an unbiased estimator of <x⃗,y⃗>\left< \vec x, \vec y \right>⟨x,y​⟩.

Proof.

If entries of σ\sigmaσ are pairwise independent, then

E[<X⃗,Y⃗>]=∑t∈[m]E[XtYt]=∑t∈[m]E[∑i,j∈[n]:h(i)=h(j)=tσiσjxiyj]=∑t∈[m]E[∑i∈[n]1mxiyi+∑i≠j1m2σiσjxiyj]=∑i∈[n]xiyi \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E} \left[ \left< \vec X, \vec Y \right> \right] &= \sum_{ t \in [m] } \mathbb{E}[ X_t Y_t ] \\ &= \sum_{ t \in [m] } \mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{ i, j \in [n] : h(i) = h(j) = t } \sigma_i \sigma_j x_i y_j \right] \\ &= \sum_{ t \in [m] } \mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{ i \in [n] } \frac{1}{m} x_i y_i + \sum_{ i \neq j } \frac{1}{m^2} \sigma_i \sigma_j x_i y_j\right] \\ &= \sum_{ i \in [n] } x_i y_i \end{aligned} E[⟨X,Y⟩]​=t∈[m]∑​E[Xt​Yt​]=t∈[m]∑​E⎣⎢⎡​i,j∈[n]:h(i)=h(j)=t∑​σi​σj​xi​yj​⎦⎥⎤​=t∈[m]∑​E⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​m1​xi​yi​+i=j∑​m21​σi​σj​xi​yj​⎦⎥⎤​=i∈[n]∑​xi​yi​​

□\square□

Theorem. Var[<X⃗,Y⃗>]≤1m⋅∥x⃗∥22⋅∥y⃗∥22\mathbb{Var} \left[ \left< \vec X, \vec Y \right> \right] \le \frac{1}{m} \cdot \Vert \vec x \Vert_2^2 \cdot \Vert \vec y \Vert_2^2Var[⟨X,Y⟩]≤m1​⋅∥x∥22​⋅∥y​∥22​.

Proof. If entries of σ\sigmaσ are four-wise independent, then

Var[<X⃗,Y⃗>]=Var[∑t∈[m]XtYt]=Var[∑i,j∈[n]:h(i)=h(j)σiσjxiyj]=Var[∑i≠j,h(i)=h(j)σiσjxiyj]=∑i≠jVar[1[h(i)=h(j)]⋅σiσjxiyj]+∑i≠j,k≠ℓ,(i,j)≠(k,ℓ)Cov[1[h(i)=h(j)]⋅σiσjxiyj,1[h(k)=h(ℓ)]⋅σkσℓxkyℓ]=∑i≠jE[(1[h(i)=h(j)]⋅σiσjxiyj)2]=∑i≠j1m⋅xi2yj2≤1m⋅∥x⃗∥22⋅∥y⃗∥22 \begin{aligned} \mathbb{Var} \left[ \left< \vec X, \vec Y \right> \right] &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{ t \in [m] } X_t Y_t \right] \\ &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{ i, j \in [n] : h(i) = h(j) } \sigma_i \sigma_j x_i y_j \right] \\ &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{ i \neq j, h(i) = h(j) } \sigma_i \sigma_j x_i y_j \right] \\ &= \sum_{i \neq j } \mathbb{Var} \left[ 1_{ [ h(i) = h (j) ] } \cdot \sigma_i \sigma_j x_i y_j \right] \\ &\quad+ \sum_{i \neq j, k \neq \ell, (i, j) \neq (k, \ell) } \mathbb{Cov} [ 1_{ [ h(i) = h (j) ] } \cdot \sigma_i \sigma_j x_i y_j, 1_{ [ h(k) = h (\ell ) ] } \cdot \sigma_k \sigma_\ell x_k y_\ell ] \\ &= \sum_{i \neq j } \mathbb{E} \left[ \left( 1_{ [ h(i) = h (j) ] } \cdot \sigma_i \sigma_j x_i y_j \right)^2 \right] \\ &= \sum_{i \neq j } \frac{1}{m} \cdot x_i^2 y_j^2 \\ &\le \frac{1}{m} \cdot \Vert \vec x \Vert_2^2 \cdot \Vert \vec y \Vert_2^2 \end{aligned} Var[⟨X,Y⟩]​=Var⎣⎢⎡​t∈[m]∑​Xt​Yt​⎦⎥⎤​=Var⎣⎢⎡​i,j∈[n]:h(i)=h(j)∑​σi​σj​xi​yj​⎦⎥⎤​=Var⎣⎢⎡​i=j,h(i)=h(j)∑​σi​σj​xi​yj​⎦⎥⎤​=i=j∑​Var[1[h(i)=h(j)]​⋅σi​σj​xi​yj​]+i=j,k=ℓ,(i,j)=(k,ℓ)∑​Cov[1[h(i)=h(j)]​⋅σi​σj​xi​yj​,1[h(k)=h(ℓ)]​⋅σk​σℓ​xk​yℓ​]=i=j∑​E[(1[h(i)=h(j)]​⋅σi​σj​xi​yj​)2]=i=j∑​m1​⋅xi2​yj2​≤m1​⋅∥x∥22​⋅∥y​∥22​​

□\square□

By setting m=1/ϵ2m = 1/ \epsilon^2m=1/ϵ2, repeating the procedure O(log⁡1δ)O(\log \frac{1}{\delta})O(logδ1​) times and taking the median as our estimation, we can obtained the desired result.

Reference

[1] G. Cormode and K. Yi, Small Summaries for Big Data, 1st ed. Cambridge University Press, 2020.
